labels.name: Service Attention
labels.description: This issue is responsible by Azure service team.

labels.name: Web Apps
labels.description: az webapp

items.body:
### **This is autogenerated. Please review and update as needed.**

## Describe the bug
We can no longer run out deployment scripts against out PROD environment since Azure CLI has been updated to `2.10.1`
**Command Name**
`az webapp create`

**Errors:**
```
The webapp '<app-service>' exists in resource group '<group>_devtest' and does not match the value entered '<group>'. Please re-run command with the correct parameters.
```

## To Reproduce:
Steps to reproduce the behavior. Note that argument values have been redacted, as they may contain sensitive information.

- _Put any pre-requisite steps here..._
- `az webapp create --resource-group {} --name {} --plan {} --only-show-errors`

## Expected Behavior
The command should pass without making any changes since the web app already exists

## Environment Summary
```
Linux-4.19.104-microsoft-standard-x86_64-with-debian-buster-sid
Python 3.6.10
Installer: DEB

azure-cli 2.10.1

```
## Additional Context
The app service we create here already exists in the resource group `<group>` and not in `<group>_devtest`.  `<group>_devtest` is a resource group we use for DEV purposes and there is and there is an app service named  '<app-service>-dev' in there. As of this version of the Azure CLI some check seems to indicate that the app service is in a different resource group then it really is
`az webapp show --resource-group {} --name {}` with the same name an resource group returns the app service object as well

items.title: `az.cmd` can't handle arguments with a `@()`

labels.name: Service Attention
labels.description: This issue is responsible by Azure service team.

items.body:
## Describe the bug

the `az.cmd` batch script that wraps `python.exe` and passes in the correct arguments to start `azure.cli` seemingly cannot handle arguments with a `@()` in them

my example is with `az webapp config connection-string set` because that is where I found it, but it most likely impacts every command

example:

```plaintext

PS C:\Users\mgrandi> # verify we have no existing connection strings in our web app
PS C:\Users\mgrandi> az webapp config connection-string list --resource-group "mgrandi-rg" --name "mgrandi-webapp"
[]

PS C:\Users\mgrandi> # try and set a connection string with a `@()` in it as the value
PS C:\Users\mgrandi> az webapp config connection-string set --connection-string-type custom --name mgrandi-webapp --settings "TestKey=@Microsoft.KeyVault(SecretUri=https://html5zombo.com)" --resource-group mgrandi-rg
--resource-group was unexpected at this time.
C:\Users\mgrandi>  "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\Azure\CLI2\wbin\\..\python.exe" -IBm azure.cli webapp config connection-string set --connection-string-type custom --name mgrandi-webapp --settings TestKey=@Microsoft.KeyVault(SecretUri=https://html5zombo.com) --resource-group mgrandi-rg
PS C:\Users\mgrandi> # note, the above is the entire output, i did not type that python.exe command

PS C:\Users\mgrandi> # verify still no connection strings
PS C:\Users\mgrandi> az webapp config connection-string list --resource-group "mgrandi-rg" --name "mgrandi-webapp"
[]

PS C:\Users\mgrandi> # try and set it with calling python.exe manually
PS C:\Users\mgrandi> & 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\Azure\CLI2\python.exe' -IBm azure.cli webapp config connection-string set --connection-string-type custom --name mgrandi-webapp --settings "TestKey=@Microsoft.KeyVault(SecretUri=https://html5zombo.com)" --resource-group mgrandi-rg
  "TestKey": {
    "type": "Custom",
    "value": "@Microsoft.KeyVault(SecretUri=https://html5zombo.com)"
  }
}

PS C:\Users\mgrandi> # verify we have one connection string now
PS C:\Users\mgrandi> az webapp config connection-string list --resource-group "mgrandi-rg" --name "mgrandi-webapp"
[
  {
    "name": "TestKey",
    "slotSetting": false,
    "type": "Custom",
    "value": "@Microsoft.KeyVault(SecretUri=https://html5zombo.com)"
  }
]


PS C:\Users\mgrandi> # if we get rid of the ending ')' , it works
PS C:\Users\mgrandi> az webapp config connection-string set --connection-string-type custom --name mgrandi-webapp --settings "TestKey2=@Microsoft.KeyVault(SecretUri=https://html5zombo.com" --resource-group mgrandi-rg
{
  "TestKey": {
    "type": "Custom",
    "value": "@Microsoft.KeyVault(SecretUri=https://html5zombo.com)"
  },
  "TestKey2": {
    "type": "Custom",
    "value": "@Microsoft.KeyVault(SecretUri=https://html5zombo.com"
  }
}


PS C:\Users\mgrandi> # should have 2 connection strings now
PS C:\Users\mgrandi> az webapp config connection-string list --resource-group "mgrandi-rg" --name "mgrandi-webapp"
[
  {
    "name": "TestKey2",
    "slotSetting": false,
    "type": "Custom",
    "value": "@Microsoft.KeyVault(SecretUri=https://html5zombo.com"
  },
  {
    "name": "TestKey",
    "slotSetting": false,
    "type": "Custom",
    "value": "@Microsoft.KeyVault(SecretUri=https://html5zombo.com)"
  }
]

```

**Command Name**
`az webapp config connection-string set`

**Errors:**

after running, you get this output to the powershell terminal

```plaintext
--resource-group was unexpected at this time.
C:\Users\mgrandi>  "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\Azure\CLI2\wbin\\..\python.exe" -IBm azure.cli webapp config connection-string set --connection-string-type custom --name mgrandi-webapp --settings TestKey=@Microsoft.KeyVault(SecretUri=https://html5zombo.com) --resource-group mgrandi-rg
```

## To Reproduce:
Steps to reproduce the behavior. Note that argument values have been redacted, as they may contain sensitive information.

- run a command with a `@()` in it


## Expected Behavior

it should pass the arguments to the python process and either work or not, depending on the arguments

## Environment Summary
```
Windows-10-10.0.18362-SP0
Python 3.6.6
Installer: MSI

azure-cli 2.9.1

```
## Additional Context

<!--Please don't remove this:-->
<!--auto-generated-->

labels.name: question
labels.description: The issue doesn't require a change to the product in order to be resolved. Most issues start as that

items.body:
## Describe the bug

The `az vm wait` command when using `--custom` crashes when I am attempting to use it. Using the example provided by [the documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/vm?view=azure-cli-latest#az-vm-wait) this crash will persist. I am trying to wait for either a stopped or deallocated state but it appears I am unable to wait for one of the two at this time.

**Command Name**
`az vm wait`

**Errors:**
```
Bad jmespath expression: Unknown token /:
instanceView.statuses[?code==PowerState/running]
                                       ^
Traceback (most recent call last):
python3.6/site-packages/knack/cli.py, ln 206, in invoke
    cmd_result = self.invocation.execute(args)
cli/core/commands/__init__.py, ln 608, in execute
    raise ex
cli/core/commands/__init__.py, ln 666, in _run_jobs_serially
    results.append(self._run_job(expanded_arg, cmd_copy))
cli/core/commands/__init__.py, ln 659, in _run_job
    six.reraise(*sys.exc_info())
...
python3.6/site-packages/jmespath/parser.py, ln 109, in _parse
    self._tokens = list(self.tokenizer)
python3.6/site-packages/jmespath/lexer.py, ln 109, in tokenize
    message="Unknown token %s" % self._current)
jmespath.exceptions.LexerError: Bad jmespath expression: Unknown token /:
instanceView.statuses[?code==PowerState/running]
                                       ^
```

## To Reproduce:
Steps to reproduce the behavior. Note that argument values have been redacted, as they may contain sensitive information.

- `az vm wait --resource-group $RESOURCE_GROUP --name $VM_NAME --custom instanceView.statuses[?code==PowerState/running]`
  - Or instanceView.statuses[?code==PowerState/deallocated] or instanceView.statuses[?code==PowerState/stopped]

## Expected Behavior

## Environment Summary
```
Linux-5.3.0-64-generic-x86_64-with
Python 3.6.9

azure-cli 2.2.0 *

```

items.title: az vm show --ids doc says space delimited, but looking for multi-line/tsv

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: This is a new issue that needs to be triaged to the appropriate team.

labels.name: question
labels.description: The issue doesn't require a change to the product in order to be resolved. Most issues start as that

items.body:
[The docs for az vm show](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/vm?view=azure-cli-latest#az-vm-show) say of the `--ids` parameter that it is looking for space delimited values

> One or more resource IDs (space-delimited). It should be a complete resource ID containing all information of 'Resource Id' arguments. You should provide either --ids or other 'Resource Id' arguments.

However, space delimited values do not appear to work, as in 

```powershell
#$allVMs comes from a filtered az resource list
$allVMIDs = ($allVMs | ForEach-Object {$_.id}) -join " "
$allVMDetails = (az vm show -g rg-name-here --ids $allVMIDs)
```
This returns only the first item in the $allVMIDs array

The CLI requires tab separated values (as shown in the many examples) or multi-line, like this
```powershell
#$allVMs comes from a filtered az resource list
$allVMIDs = $allVMs | ForEach-Object {$_.id}
$allVMDetails = (az vm show -g rg-name-here --ids $allVMIDs)
```
If this isn't just another PowerShell Core / CLI oddity the documentation should be updated

My details:
```
{
  "azure-cli": "2.9.1",
  "azure-cli-command-modules-nspkg": "2.0.3",
  "azure-cli-core": "2.9.1",

```

items.title: Webapp:Can't set a setting that contains a | char

labels.name: Service Attention
labels.description: This issue is responsible by Azure service team.

labels.name: Web Apps
labels.description: az webapp

items.body:
I am using powershell, and trying to use the `az webapp config appsettings set` command to set an appsetting, and am following this document.

My setting value, contains a `|` character. I tried this:

```
 az webapp config appsettings set --name uniun-prod --resource-group production --slot-settings Foo=foo|bar
```

I get:

> bar : The term 'bar' is not recognized as the name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or operable program. Check the
spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.

I tried to escape the pipe character. Powershell rules say backtick is used to escape special chars:

```
 az webapp config appsettings set --name uniun-prod --resource-group production --slot-settings Foo=foo`|bar
```

Same error:

> 'bar' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.

I try to quote the string:

```
 az webapp config appsettings set --name uniun-prod --resource-group production --slot-settings Foo='foo|bar'
```

Same error:

> 'bar' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.


I try to declare the variable first, then use it:

```
$fooValue = 'foo|bar'
az webapp config appsettings set --name uniun-prod --resource-group production --slot-settings Foo=$fooValue 
```

Same error.

Absolutely pulling my hair out now. How do I set this value?

Lastly I tried using a double `||`

```
 az webapp config appsettings set --name uniun-prod --resource-group production --slot-settings 'Foo=1||2'
```

That set the variable to `1` so it seemed to evaluate the `||` as an "or else" even though I am passing it as a literal string arguement:

```
 {
    "name": "Foo",
    "slotSetting": true,
    "value": "1"
  }

```
So to me, this is seeming like its a limitation of the command itself and that it seems to interpret pipe characters. 

---

items.title: WebApp Cert Bind - can't find cert

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: This is a new issue that needs to be triaged to the appropriate team.

labels.name: question
labels.description: The issue doesn't require a change to the product in order to be resolved. Most issues start as that

items.body:
## Describe the bug

**Command Name**
`az webapp config ssl bind`

**Errors:**
```
Certificate for thumbprint 'XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX' not found.
```

## To Reproduce:
Steps to reproduce the behavior. Note that argument values have been redacted, as they may contain sensitive information.

- create an app service plan (premiumV2) and a web app for containers (linux), in different resource groups but same sub
- add a verified custom domain name (cname & txt records)
- `az webapp config ssl create --resource-group {} --name {} --hostname {}` # works fine
- get the {certificate_thumbprint} from the json object output and set in next step
- **`az webapp config ssl bind --resource-group {} --name {} --ssl-type SNI --certificate-thumbprint {}`**

## Expected Behavior

Bind the managed certificate to the custom hostname in the web app.

## Environment Summary
```
macOS-11.0-x86_64-i386-64bit
Python 3.8.5
Installer: HOMEBREW

azure-cli 2.10.0
```
## Additional Context

I ran in debug mode and it clearly switches contexts from searching for the certificate under the webapp to the underlying server farm. Instead of running:

```http
GET /subscriptions/{sub}/resourceGroups/{rg}/providers/Microsoft.Web/certificates
```
with {rg} of the webapp, it runs:

```http
GET /subscriptions/{sub}/resourceGroups/{other-rg}/providers/Microsoft.Web/certificates
```
with {other-rg} of the webapp's serverfarm when searching for the certificate by its thumbprint.

Thumbprint is also not the best ID to use here, cant we use the certificate ARM ID? e.g. 

`/subscriptions/{}/resourceGroups/{}/providers/Microsoft.Web/certificates/{custom-domain-name}`

as when the certificate gets rotated, it will change the thumbprint?

items.title: Output cannot be formatted to table - when listing objects and using --query

labels.name: Interactive
labels.description: az interactive

items.body:
Hello, I'm working with webapps, vms, and other objects throguh CLI,
I am able to query those objects, rename columns, etc,
but when I use --query - I am unable to eventually display the output as table.
I have followed this documentation page - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/query-azure-cli?view=azure-cli-latest step by step.

**Describe the bug**
I am running those commands, for example:
- `az vm list -g {} --query {}`
- `az webapp list -g {} --query {}`

Works just fine - returns the expected json result.

But when I run them with `-o table` at the end, like this:
- `az vm list -g {} --query {} -o table`
- `az webapp list -g {} --query {} -o table`

Error is thrown:
`Table output unavailable. Use the --query option to specify an appropriate query. Use --debug for more info.`

**To Reproduce**
Run commands such as:
- `az vm list -g {} --query {}`
- `az webapp list -g {} --query {}`
Validate that those are working.

Then, run those commands again with `-o table` at the end of the line.

**Environment summary**

Windows-10-10.0.18362-SP0
Python 3.6.6
Installer: MSI
Extensions:
interactive 0.4.4

Update (8/4/20, 10:30) update: Tried on two other windows 10 workstations with differenet cli version and issue is reproduced just the same.

**Additional context**
1. I am using interactive mode.
2. I updated both azure-cli and interactive mode 10 mintues ago, and it didn't help.
3. Issue reproduced and error just the same in azure cloud shell.
4. In addition, I would like to let you know that I googled the issue and saw few github posts in which the issue have already been reported. I did not find any appropriate solution in any of those posts.
5. Update (8/4/20, 10:30):  This issue has been opened 3 days ago - https://github.com/Azure/azure-cli/issues/14615.
In my intuition, according to the similarity of the issues it really seems like the problem is not client-specific, nor version-specific, and not object-specific.

items.title: Private Python packages for remote build

labels.name: Feature Request
labels.description: This issue requires a new behavior in the product in order be resolved.

items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
We have an internal PyPI index to which we deploy private packages that we'd then like to pip install into our Python Azure function. Because our packaging index is not reachable from the Azure cloud we've so far opted for `--build local`. However, this has turned out to be a bit fragile as a couple of times now after adding new dependencies we get errors like these:

`There was an error restoring dependencies. ERROR: cannot install pyrsistent-0.16.0 dependency: binary dependencies without wheels are not supported when building locally. Use the "--build remote" option to build dependencies on the Azure Functions build server, or "--build-native-deps" option to automatically build and configure the dependencies using a Docker container. More information at https://aka.ms/func-python-publish`

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Hence I was wondering whether it isn't possible to first pip install our couple private packages on our CI runner into a magic folder and have that folder uploaded to Azure to be considered in an otherwise standard remote build - or something along those lines.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I'd rather not get into the `--build-native-deps` option if I can avoid it as the CI runners we're using aren't under our control and I don't know how straight-forward it would be to have them configured for `--build-native-deps`.

items.title: Metadata key-value pairs get set incorrectly on policy definition creation

labels.name: ARM
labels.description: az resource/group/lock/tag/deployment/policy/managementapp/account management-group

labels.name: Feature Request
labels.description: This issue requires a new behavior in the product in order be resolved.

milestone.title: S174
milestone.description: POC: @Juliehzl @fengzhou-msft Code complete: 08/19/2020 Build to Cloud Shell: 08/21/2020 Official Release: 08/25/2020

items.body:
**Describe the bug**
When providing multiple metadata key=value pairs on policy definition creation, every pair after the first one gets appended to the first pair's key.

**To Reproduce**
```bash
params='{ "listOfAllowedLocations": { "allowedValues": null, "defaultValue": null, "metadata": { "description": "The list of locations that can be specified when deploying resources.", "displayName": "Allowed locations", "strongType": "location" }, "type": "Array" } }'

rules=$(cat << 'HEREDOC'
{ "if": { "allOf": [ { "field": "location", "notIn": "[parameters('listOfAllowedLocations')]" }, { "field": "location", "notEquals": "global" }, { "field": "type", "notEquals": "Microsoft.AzureActisveDirectory/b2cDirectories" } ] }, "then": { "effect": "deny" } }
HEREDOC
)

az policy definition create --name az-bug-report-2020-07-30 --rules "$rules" --params "$params" --metadata 'version=1.0.0 category=location'
```

The created policy has the second key-value pair (`category=location`) added to the first pair's value (`version=1.0.0 category=location`) instead of being under a new key. Here's the created policy:

```json
{
  "description": null,
  "displayName": null,
  "id": "/subscriptions/REDACTED/providers/Microsoft.Authorization/policyDefinitions/az-bug-report-2020-07-30",
  "metadata": {
    "createdBy": "REDACTED",
    "createdOn": "2020-07-30T10:30:41.6720972Z",
    "updatedBy": null,
    "updatedOn": null,
    "version": "1.0.0 category=location"
  },
 ...
```

**Expected behavior**
Metadata pairs created separately, like:

```json
{
  "description": null,
  "displayName": null,
  "id": "/subscriptions/REDACTED/providers/Microsoft.Authorization/policyDefinitions/az-bug-report-2020-07-30",
  "metadata": {
    "createdBy": "REDACTED",
    "createdOn": "2020-07-30T10:30:41.6720972Z",
    "updatedBy": null,
    "updatedOn": null,
    "version": "1.0.0",
    "category": "location"
  },
 ...
```

**Environment summary**

Installed from [official RPM](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/install-azure-cli-yum?view=azure-cli-latest), shell is Bash.

```bash
az --version
azure-cli                          2.9.1

command-modules-nspkg              2.0.3
core                               2.9.1
nspkg                              3.0.4
telemetry                          1.0.4

Python location '/usr/bin/python3'
Extensions directory '/home/REDACTED/.azure/cliextensions'

Python (Linux) 3.6.8 (default, Sep 26 2019, 11:57:09) 
[GCC 4.8.5 20150623 (Red Hat 4.8.5-39)]

Legal docs and information: aka.ms/AzureCliLegal


Your CLI is up-to-date.
```

**Additional context**
According to the [documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/policy/definition?view=azure-cli-latest#az-policy-definition-create-optional-parameters), metadata shall be set as `space-separated key=value pairs`

Because, or azure function team did not update the extension bundle (the one that is added by default when you create a new azure function instance).

Here is the error:
Microsoft.Azure.WebJobs.Host: Error indexing method 'Functions.Bounce'. Microsoft.Azure.WebJobs.Extensions.Storage: Can't bind Table to type 'Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.Table.CloudTable'.

Here is the stacktrace.

items.title: Allow users to set `allowBlobPublicAccess` with a flag on `az storage account create`

labels.name: Feature Request
labels.description: This issue requires a new behavior in the product in order be resolved.

labels.name: Storage
labels.description: az storage

milestone.title: S174
milestone.description: POC: @Juliehzl @fengzhou-msft Code complete: 08/19/2020 Build to Cloud Shell: 08/21/2020 Official Release: 08/25/2020

items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
<!--- A clear and concise description of what the problem is. Ex. I'm always frustrated when [...] --->

My company recently changed security policy - All storage accounts created must have the `allowBlobPublicAccess` property ( https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/blobs/anonymous-read-access-configure?tabs=azure-cli ) disabled. However, I think this means it will be impossible for our engineers to use `az storage account create` to create storage accounts - we can't set that field on creation (that I know of, happy to be shown a counter example).

**Describe the solution you'd like**
<!--- A clear and concise description of what you want to happen. --->

Allow users to set `allowBlobPublicAccess` with a flag on `az storage account create`

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
<!--- A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or features you've considered. --->

Engineers can still:

- use the portal to create storage accounts (not as reproducible as saving a command and its output)
- Use the `az resource create` method to create storage accounts - much harder to find the right combination of flags and such

**Additional context**
<!--- Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here. --->

This flag is visible in the "Configuration" sidebar when looking at a storage account in the Azure portal.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6081085/88740563-61d16f80-d0f2-11ea-87b5-2a655fb7629e.png)

items.title: Triggering only on a change to the contents of a github repo folder

labels.name: Container Registry
labels.description: az acr

labels.name: Feature Request
labels.description: This issue requires a new behavior in the product in order be resolved.

labels.name: Service Attention
labels.description: This issue is responsible by Azure service team.

items.body:
Hi, 

I have my triggers setup to specify on branch and folder in a Github repo, but the ACR tasks are being triggered for changes to files outside of the specified folder.

Is it possible to only trigger on a push for the contents of the folder? Otherwise it looks like we can only have one task per repo.


In the example below I'd expect that a Task run only to occur when the contents of `task_folder` is changed.

```
   "sourceTriggers": [
      {
        "name": "defaultSourceTriggerName",
        "sourceRepository": {
          "branch": "master",
          "repositoryUrl": "https://github.com/A30004028/cloud.container.images.git#master:task_folder",
          "sourceControlAuthProperties": null,
          "sourceControlType": "Github"
        },
        "sourceTriggerEvents": [
          "commit"
        ],
        "status": "Enabled"
      }
    ],
```

Thanks
Mark

items.title: az network application-gateway auth-cert show : clarification on certificate format

labels.name: Feature Request
labels.description: This issue requires a new behavior in the product in order be resolved.

labels.name: Network
labels.description: az network vnet/lb/nic/dns/etc...

labels.name: Network - Application Gateway
labels.description: az network application-gateway

milestone.title: S174
milestone.description: POC: @Juliehzl @fengzhou-msft Code complete: 08/19/2020 Build to Cloud Shell: 08/21/2020 Official Release: 08/25/2020

items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
The authorization certificates of an application gateway can be found as follows:

`az network application-gateway auth-cert show -g test-rg --gateway-name test-aag --name test.com --query data`

Note: Argument values have been redacted to hide sensitive information

However, the certificate data is displayed in raw format. After trying around different options, I found that the certificate shown is base64 encoded CER certificate which was uploaded. To retrieve information from the certificate (like expiry date), the data needs to be base64 decoded first and then queried with openssl to retrieve the expiration date.

Example:

`$ az network application-gateway auth-cert show -g test-rg --gateway-name test-aag --name test.com --query data -o tsv | base64 --decode | openssl x509 -enddate -noout`
`notAfter=Jul 30 12:00:00 2020 GMT`

**Describe the solution you'd like**
It would be a good idea to add this as an example in the help message and documentation. It would be pretty helpful as without this information, it takes some effort to get the correct format and information. Please review this and provide guidance.

items.title: Cannot switch between OWASP rule sets using add/remove or update in WAF_v2

labels.name: Feature Request
labels.description: This issue requires a new behavior in the product in order be resolved.

labels.name: Network
labels.description: az network vnet/lb/nic/dns/etc...

milestone.title: S174
milestone.description: POC: @Juliehzl @fengzhou-msft Code complete: 08/19/2020 Build to Cloud Shell: 08/21/2020 Official Release: 08/25/2020

items.body:
Due to how the WAF_v2 is setup, you need at least one set of OWASP rules enabled, and by default, the CLI creates the WAF using OWASP 3.0 (instead of 2.2.9 or 3.1), and there's no way in `az network application-gateway waf-policy create` to specify the OWASP version.

My first line of thinking was to add OWASP 3.1 using `az network application-gateway waf-policy managed-rule rule-set add`, but it failed silently with no errors. Same when I tried to remove OWASP 3.0 using `az network application-gateway waf-policy managed-rule rule-set remove`. 

My logical thinking was then to use `az network application-gateway waf-policy managed-rule rule-set update`, with `--type OWASP --version 3.1`...but the `update` action requires the `--group-name` argument, even if we're not managing rules but rather rule-sets.

Thus, the current status of Azure CLI makes it impossible to create a new WAF Policy in WAF_v2 and use OWASP 3.1, it has to be done manually in the portal.

Suggested fixes:
- Disable the requirement for the `--group-name` argument, and only make it a requirement if paired with `--rules`. so that we can switch over between OWASP rule set versions
- Make it possible to set the initial OWASP rule set version at creation, to prevent having to rely on a second command to then switch over.
---

items.title: [Compute] automatic in-guest patching

labels.name: Compute
labels.description: az vm/vmss/image/disk

labels.name: Feature Request
labels.description: This issue requires a new behavior in the product in order be resolved.

milestone.title: S174
milestone.description: POC: @Juliehzl @fengzhou-msft Code complete: 08/19/2020 Build to Cloud Shell: 08/21/2020 Official Release: 08/25/2020

items.body:
**Resource Provider**
<!--- What is the Azure resource provider your feature is part of? --->
Compute

**Description of Feature or Work Requested**
<!--- Provide a brief description of the feature or work requested. A link to conceptual documentation may be helpful too. --->

Automatic in-guest patching provides customers an easy-to-onboard solution to maintain security compliance for their virtual machines. This feature provides:
1.	Simple onboarding – Enrolling a VM requires configuring one property on the VM model (process detailed below) with no further onboarding actions needed.
2.	Automatic compliance – Most VMs (including dev/test) have compliance requirements for security/critical vulnerabilities and using automatic in-guest patching keeps the virtual machine compliant without additional overhead.
3.	Availability-first patching – Automatic in-guest patching is orchestrated through an availability-first process (detailed below) which ensures maximum uptime for the customer’s application.

To onboard a new VM to automatic in-guest patching, the following property settings must be included in the VM model/template:
"windowsConfiguration": {
  "provisionVMAgent": true,
  "enableAutomaticUpdates": true,
  "patchSettings": {
    "patchMode": "AutomaticByPlatform"
   }
}

CLI support is requested to set the above flag on the VM model when creating the VM or modifying it.

In addition, the az vm get-instance-view cmdlet will also need to be updated to use the latest 2020-06-01 API version (if not already done).


**Minimum API Version Required**
<!--- What is the minimum API version of your service required to implement your feature? --->
2020-06-01

**Swagger Link**
<!--- Provide a link to the location of your feature(s) in the REST API specs repo. If your feature(s) has corresponding commit or pull request in the REST API specs repo, provide them. This should be on the master branch of the REST API specs repo. --->

Here is the doc : https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.azure.management.compute.models.windowsconfiguration.patchsettings?view=azure-dotnet

items.body:

**Describe the bug**

"I am creating app registrations in our AAD using DevOps release pipelines and Azure CLI component with Powershell. I am running into an issue when running the commands within an inline script with a parser in az cli that is taking my app role description and breaking up the input into a list of values at the spaces within the description. I've run the same script via command line in local powershell and don't experience the same parsing issue.

 

Is there anyway to escape the spaces such that the parse won't behave this way?

 

Your guidance/suggested will be greatly appreciated."


**To Reproduce**
The az cli command I am building starts with

az ad app create --display-name "myAppReg" --reply-urls "https://myAppName.azurewebsites.net/.auth/login/aad/callback"

(obvious changes). This works fine.

 

When I try to add --app-roles with value (manifest json format)

"[{'allowedMemberTypes':['User'],'description':'Users have the ability to create, modify, and delete workflow items.','displayName':'User','isEnabled':true,'value':'User'}]"
"[{\"allowedMemberTypes\":[\"User\"],\"description\":\"Users have the ability to create, modify, and delete workflow items.\",\"displayName\":\"User\",\"isEnabled\":true,\"value\":\"User\"}]"
'[{\"allowedMemberTypes\":[\"User\"],\"description\":\"Users have the ability to create, modify, and delete workflow items.\",\"displayName\":\"User\",\"isEnabled\":true,\"value\":\"User\"}]'
'[{"allowedMemberTypes":["User"],"description":"Users have the ability to create, modify, and delete workflow items.","displayName":"User","isEnabled":true,"value":"User"}]'
 

I receive "Expecting property name enclosed in double quotes: line 1 column 3 (char 2)".

 

Adding the "--debug" to the end of the az command shows:

 

Command arguments: ['ad', 'app', 'create', '--display-name', 'myAppReg', '--app-roles', '[{\\', 'allowedMemberTypes\\:[\\User\\],\\description\\:\\Users', 'have', 'the', 'ability', 'to', 'create,', 'modify,', 'and', 'delete', 'workflow', 'items.\\,\\displayName\\:\\User\\,\\isEnabled\\:true,\\value\\:\\User\\}]', '--reply-urls', 'https://myAppName.azurewebsites.net/.auth/login/aad/callback', '--debug']

 

My script contains the following function

 

Function New-AppRegistration {

    [CmdletBinding()]

    Param(

        [string] $DisplayName,

        [string] $AppRoles = "",

        [string] $ReplyUrls = ""

    )

 

    $appInfo = (az ad app list --display-name $DisplayName) | ConvertFrom-Json

 

    if (!$appInfo) {

        $cmd = "az ad app create --display-name ""$($DisplayName)"""

 

        if ($AppRoles) {

            $AppRoles = $AppRoles.Replace("'",'\"')

            $cmd += @"

 --app-roles "$($AppRoles)"

"@

        }

        if ($ReplyUrls) { $cmd += " --reply-urls ""$($ReplyUrls)"""}

        $cmd += " --debug"

 

        $sb = [scriptblock]::Create($cmd)

        $appInfo = (Invoke-Command -ScriptBlock $sb | ConvertFrom-Json)

        if (!$appInfo){

            Write-Error "Error creating application registration for '$($DisplayName)'."

        }

    }

    return $appInfo.appId

}

 

I appreciate the response greatly."

**Expected behavior**

"here is the command line version that works:

az ad app create --display-name "myAppReg" --reply-urls "https://myApp.azurewebsites.net/.auth/login/aad/callback" --app-roles "[{'allowedMemberTypes':['User'],'description':'Users have the ability to create, modify, and delete workflow items.','displayName':'User','isEnabled':true,'value':'User'}]".Replace("'",'\"')

 

This has been my target for the script."

items.title: Unable to encode the output with cp1252 encoding. Unsupported characters are discarded.

labels.name: Feature Request
labels.description: This issue requires a new behavior in the product in order be resolved.

labels.name: Graph
labels.description: az ad

milestone.title: S174
milestone.description: POC: @Juliehzl @fengzhou-msft Code complete: 08/19/2020 Build to Cloud Shell: 08/21/2020 Official Release: 08/25/2020

items.body:
**Describe the bug**

I don't know if this is specific to the command that I am about to reference, but whenever I run the command

```
az ad sp list --all
```

in a powershell console, the console window will return the message "Unable to encode the output with cp1252 encoding. Unsupported characters are discarded" to the console before processing the command.  To be more specific, the message does **NOT** appear if I run the command as displayed about and just output the result to the console.  The error occurs when I attempt to integrate it with powershell in some way.  For example, the error will display if I attempt to assign the output to a variable:

```
$output = az ad sp list --all
```

Another example is if I attempt to pipe the output from the command to the "Convertfrom-Json" cmdlet (since the output is a json string):

```
az ad sp list --all | Convertfrom-json
```

Just so that we are 100% clear here, it does not **appear** that the command is failing in its entirety.  It does return output when I run the above two commands, but, as the error itself states, I don't know if what I am seeing is the entire return.  And if it is, then the error message shouldn't give that impression by being displayed in the first place.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64720591/87964045-2a871100-caa9-11ea-8074-5252c56e1bd5.png)



**To Reproduce**
1. login to azure using az login in a powershell console
2. Run either of these commands

```
$output = az ad sp list --all
```

```
az ad sp list --all | Convertfrom-json
```

**Expected behavior**
The azure cli should not be returning an error indicating that certain characters might have been dropped from the results of a command just because it was run in a powershell console.  And if no characters were dropped, then the azure cli should not display the error in the first place.

**Environment summary**
Running on a windows 10 pro computer and installed using the msi installer downloaded from Microsoft's website

items.title: Azure DNS zone export missing trailing "." on MX, NS, PTR, SRV record targets

labels.name: Feature Request
labels.description: This issue requires a new behavior in the product in order be resolved.

labels.name: Network
labels.description: az network vnet/lb/nic/dns/etc...

labels.name: bug
labels.description: This issue requires a change to an existing behavior in the product in order to be resolved.

milestone.title: S174
milestone.description: POC: @Juliehzl @fengzhou-msft Code complete: 08/19/2020 Build to Cloud Shell: 08/21/2020 Official Release: 08/25/2020

items.body:
**Describe the bug**
When exporting a DNS zone from Azure DNS, MX/NS/PTR/SRV record type targets don't get a trailing "." appended which means the zone file is incorrect.

**To Reproduce**
az network dns zone create -g <resource group> -n <zone name>
az network dns record-set mx add-record -e contoso.com -p 0 -n mxtest -g <resource group> -z <zone name>
az network dns record-set ns add-record -d ns.contoso.com -n nstest -g <resource group> -z <zone name>
az network dns record-set ptr add-record -d "ptr.contoso.com" -n ptrtest -g <resource group> -z <zone name>
az network dns record-set srv add-record -r 443 -p 0 -t srv.contoso.com -w 0 -n srvtest -g <resource group> -z <zone name>
az network dns zone export -g <resource group> -n <zone name>

The output of the export of those records will look as follows:

mxtest 3600 IN MX 0 contoso.com
nstest 3600 IN NS ns.contoso.com
ptrtest 3600 IN PTR ptr.contoso.com
srvtest 3600 IN SRV 0 0 443 srv.contoso.com

**Expected behavior**
The output should have a trailing "." on those 4 records as below to make them FQDNs instead of relative names. Azure DNS treats all targets in these record types as FQDNs so the CLI export should treat them as such. Without this trailing "." it will cause these record type values to be incorrect when loading this export into another DNS server such as BIND or even when re-importing using "az network dns zone import" by wrongly appending the zone name.

mxtest 3600 IN MX 0 contoso.com.
nstest 3600 IN NS ns.contoso.com.
ptrtest 3600 IN PTR ptr.contoso.com.
srvtest 3600 IN SRV 0 0 443 srv.contoso.com.

**Environment summary**

Windows-10-10.0.19041-SP0
Python 3.6.6
Installer: MSI

azure-cli 2.9.1

**Additional context**
The CNAME and SOA record types seem to behave correctly already. Please make MX, NS, PTR, SRV target values behave as those. Do note there should only be exactly 1 trailing "." at the end. If the existing record contains one already, then we should not append another.

    "publicIPAddressConfiguration": {
        "ipAddressIds": [
            "/subscriptions/<subscriptionId>/resourceGroups/<resourceGroup>/providers/Microsoft.Network/publicIPAddresses/<publicIpId0>",
            "/subscriptions/<subscriptionId>/resourceGroups/<resourceGroup>/providers/Microsoft.Network/publicIPAddresses/<publicIpId1>",
            "/subscriptions/<subscriptionId>/resourceGroups/<resourceGroup>/providers/Microsoft.Network/publicIPAddresses/<publicIpId2>",
            "/subscriptions/<subscriptionId>/resourceGroups/<resourceGroup>/providers/Microsoft.Network/publicIPAddresses/<publicIpId3>"
        ]
    }
}
```
When I am using version 2.9.1 of the az-cli, the batch pool is created successfully but it is using the dynamically generated public IP addresses and JSON view shows as follows:
```
"networkConfiguration": {
    "subnetId": "/subscriptions/<subscriptionId>/resourceGroups/<resourceGroup>/providers/Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks/<vNetId>/subnets/<subnetId>",
    "dynamicVNetAssignmentScope": "none"
}
```

When I use an older version of the az-cli (I used 2.1.0 via the docker image: mcr.microsoft.com/azure-cli:2.1.0), the publicIps are present in the configurations as expected:
```
"networkConfiguration": {
    "subnetId": "/subscriptions/<subscriptionId>/resourceGroups/<resourceGroup>/providers/Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks/<vNetId>/subnets/<subnetId>",
    "dynamicVNetAssignmentScope": "none",
    "publicIPAddressConfiguration": {
        "ipAddressIds": [
            "/subscriptions/<subscriptionId>/resourceGroups/<resourceGroup>/providers/Microsoft.Network/publicIPAddresses/<publicIpId0>",
            "/subscriptions/<subscriptionId>/resourceGroups/<resourceGroup>/providers/Microsoft.Network/publicIPAddresses/<publicIpId1>",
            "/subscriptions/<subscriptionId>/resourceGroups/<resourceGroup>/providers/Microsoft.Network/publicIPAddresses/<publicIpId2>",
            "/subscriptions/<subscriptionId>/resourceGroups/<resourceGroup>/providers/Microsoft.Network/publicIPAddresses/<publicIpId3>"
        ]
    }
}
```

**To Reproduce**
Create an azure batch pool with publicIps in the networkConfiguration.

**Expected behavior**
Batch pool is created with the correct publicIps in the JSON view under batch pool properties.

## Environment Summary
```
macOS-10.15.5-x86_64-i386-64bit
Python 3.8.4
Installer: HOMEBREW

azure-cli 2.9.1
```

Verify runtime version from `az webapp config show` command: Should be php 7.3 instead of 5.x
